tab The QPCR data were further analyzed to examine sex differences in the expression of CCK, PC1, PC2 (wild type only), and PC5 (TABLE FIVE). Of the 43 comparisons made, in 11 cases, females were higher than males; this was observed more often with CCK and PC5. These differences were equally distributed between wild type and knock-outs. In only one case (wild-type males), CCK was higher in males than females. The molecular forms of CCK in PFC and hippocampus extracts were separated by HPLC and measured with the CCK RIA. The major form detected co-eluted with synthetic CCK8 sulfate in both wild-type and knock-out tissue extracts from both tissues (Fig. 2). The identity of the peak eluting earlier than CCK8 in the PFC is not known. It does not elute with sulfated CCK12, CCK22, or CCK33. It is unlikely to be oxidized CCK8, which elutes much earlier on the column, near the void volume (25.Beinfeld M.C. Jensen R.T. Brownstein M.J. J. Liquid Chromatog. 1980; 3: 1367-1371Crossref Scopus (21) Google Scholar). It does appear to be somewhat more prominent in the knock-out sample. In the absence of PC2, CCK levels were reduced in hippocampus, VTA/SN, septum, thalamus, and pons. This is consistent with previous anatomical studies, as PC2 is highly co-localized with CCK in hippocampus, VTA/SN, and thalamus (13.Cain B. Connolly K. Blum A. Vishnuvardhan D. Marchand J.E. Beinfeld M.C. J. Comp. Neurol. 2003; 467: 307-325Crossref PubMed Scopus (30) Google Scholar). The septum receives a major CCK projection from the hippocampus (26.Handelmann G. Beinfeld M.C. O'Donohue T.L. Nelson J.B. Brenneman D.E. Peptides. 1983; 4: 331-334Crossref PubMed Scopus (24) Google Scholar), so the level of CCK in the septum probably reflects the decreased level in the hippocampus. As described in previous publications (20.Vishnuvardhan D. Connolly K. Cain B. Beinfeld M.C. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 2000; 273: 188-191Crossref PubMed Scopus (27) Google Scholar, 21.Rehfeld J.F. Lindberg I. Friis-Hansen L. J. Neurochem. 2002; 83: 1329-1337Crossref PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar), the loss of PC2 decreases CCK levels in specific brain regions. The lack of change of CCK levels in the hypothalamus, and the decrease in forebrain (minus cerebral cortex and hypothalamus) in the previous study (20.Vishnuvardhan D. Connolly K. Cain B. Beinfeld M.C. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 2000; 273: 188-191Crossref PubMed Scopus (27) Google Scholar) is consistent with the results of the current study. The decrease in CCK levels in whole mouse brain (21.Rehfeld J.F. Lindberg I. Friis-Hansen L. J. Neurochem. 2002; 83: 1329-1337Crossref PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar) and in cerebral cortex (20.Vishnuvardhan D. Connolly K. Cain B. Beinfeld M.C. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 2000; 273: 188-191Crossref PubMed Scopus (27) Google Scholar) is puzzling in light of the current study. Indeed, differences in methods of euthanasia and tissue dissection were used. It is conceivable that CCK is elevated in only some brain regions (in particular PFC and temporal cortex) so that when other areas where CCK might be reduced are combined, CCK levels actually go down. The increase in glycine extended CCK peptides in PFC seen in the current study was also seen in whole brain in the previous study (21.Rehfeld J.F. Lindberg I. Friis-Hansen L. J. Neurochem. 2002; 83: 1329-1337Crossref PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar). Female knock-out mice were more affected by the loss of PC2 than male mice. With some exceptions, female mice of both genotypes had higher levels of CCK, PC1, PC2, and PC5 mRNA than males. These sex differences emphasize the importance of examining the effects of the loss of individual genes in both genders. The loss of PC2 did not change the major form of CCK produced by cerebral cortex or hippocampus. Whichever enzyme(s) process pro-CCK in the absence of PC2 seem to produce the same major product. It is clear that PC2 is important for production of CCK in some brain regions, most notably hippocampus, thalamus, septum, VTA/SN, and pons where the loss of PC2 results in lower levels of CCK. Based on the number of areas having increased and decreased CCK levels in PC2 knock-out mice as compared with the PC1 knock-out mice (14.Cain B.M. Connolly K. Blum A.C. Vishnuvardhan D. Marchand J.E. Zhu X. Steiner D.F. Beinfeld M.C. J. Neurochem. 2004; 89: 307-313Crossref PubMed Scopus (19) Google Scholar), the loss of PC2 appears to have greater consequences for CCK processing. The loss of PC1 (14.Cain B.M. Connolly K. Blum A.C. Vishnuvardhan D. Marchand J.E. Zhu X. Steiner D.F. Beinfeld M.C. J. Neurochem. 2004; 89: 307-313Crossref PubMed Scopus (19) Google Scholar) also reduced CCK levels in the hippocampus, suggesting that PC1 and PC2 may together be responsible for the majority of CCK processing in this structure. In all tissues examined in both knock-outs, there was never a complete loss of CCK, suggesting that redundancy exists in the enzymes that process pro-CCK. Neither PC1 nor PC5 were up-regulated by the loss of PC2, but existing levels of these enzymes may be adequate to ensure production of some CCK. Increased CCK levels in the olfactory bulb in PC2 knock-out raises an interesting question about the identity of the enzyme(s) responsible for CCK processing in this structure. In a previous anatomical study of rat brain (13.Cain B. Connolly K. Blum A. Vishnuvardhan D. Marchand J.E. Beinfeld M.C. J. Comp. Neurol. 2003; 467: 307-325Crossref PubMed Scopus (30) Google Scholar), PC2 was highly co-localized, PC1 was somewhat co-localized whereas PC5 showed little co-localization with CCK in the olfactory bulb. PC1 knock-out mice had the same levels of CCK as the wild-type mice in their olfactory bulbs (14.Cain B.M. Connolly K. Blum A.C. Vishnuvardhan D. Marchand J.E. Zhu X. Steiner D.F. Beinfeld M.C. J. Neurochem. 2004; 89: 307-313Crossref PubMed Scopus (19) Google Scholar) and PC2 knock-out mice had elevated CCK levels. These observations provide good evidence that none of these enzymes are responsible for the processing of CCK in this structure. Two other members of the PC family (PC7 and PACE4) are present in the olfactory bulb (12.Dong W. Marcinkiewicz M. Vieau D. Chrétien M. Seidah N.G. Day R. J. Neurosci. 1995; 15: 1778-1796Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 27.Seidah N.G. Hamelin J. Mamarbachi M. Dong W. Tadros H. Mbikay M. Chretien M. Day R. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1996; 93: 3388-3393Crossref PubMed Scopus (224) Google Scholar) and may be responsible for CCK processing there. The increase in CCK levels in olfactory bulb, cerebral cortex and structures receiving CCK innervations from the cerebral cortex is intriguing. Because CCK is increased in both PFC and temporal cortex, this appears to be a generalized cerebral cortical phenomenon. A previous study (21.Rehfeld J.F. Lindberg I. Friis-Hansen L. J. Neurochem. 2002; 83: 1329-1337Crossref PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar) found increased levels of glycine extended CCK in whole PC2 knock-out brains relative to control, whereas levels of amidated CCK decreased. The current study found CCK-Gly levels to be elevated in PFC but not in hippocampus whereas CCK levels increased in PFC and decreased in hippocampus. The regional heterogeneity of this phenotype points out the importance of closely examining individual brain regions. It is not known how the loss of PC2 produces elevated levels of CCK in the PFC and olfactory bulb. Total precursor levels are elevated in PFC, which provides the substrate for higher levels of amidated CCK. Higher levels of glycine extended CCK in the knock-outs before trypsin and carboxypeptidase treatment are consistent with increased enzymatic activity. The loss of PC2 may have stimulated the expression or activity of another enzyme that is able to process CCK and resulted in higher levels of CCK-Gly and CCK amide. The increase in CCK in the olfactory bulb is not caused by cerebral cortical innervation as CCK is present in local interneurons within the bulb. It is possible that the same mechanism that raises levels of CCK in the cortex is also operating in the bulb. It is possible that the decrease in expression of CCK and PC1 mRNA and the increased levels of amidated CCK are actually related. The CCK (28.Hansen T.V. Rehfeld J.F. Nielsen F.C. Mol. Endocrinol. 1999; 13: 466-475PubMed Google Scholar, 29.Nielsen F.C. Pedersen K. Hansen T.V.O. Rourke I.J. Rehfeld J.F. DNA Cell Biol. 1996; 15: 53-63Crossref PubMed Scopus (46) Google Scholar) and PC1 (30.Jansen E. Ayoubi T.A. Meulemans S.M. Van de Ven W.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 15391-15397Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (56) Google Scholar, 31.Jansen E. Ayoubi T.A. Meulemans S.M. Van de Ven W.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 2500-2508Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (30) Google Scholar) promoters both have cAMP response elements, and cAMP is known to stimulate CCK release from rat brain slices (32.Beinfeld M.C. Regul. Pept. 1996; 67: 75-77Crossref PubMed Scopus (5) Google Scholar) and endocrine tumor cells (17.Yoon J.Y. Beinfeld M.C. Endocrine. 1994; 2: 973-977Google Scholar). It is possible that the loss of PC2 reduces the processing of another peptide or protein that normally stimulates cAMP. This reduction in cAMP could decrease expression of CCK and PC1 mRNA and decrease the release of CCK in the cerebral cortex. This could cause an accumulation of CCK in vesicles resulting in higher tissue levels of CCK. This mechanism may not be unique to CCK. Similar mechanisms may be responsible for increased levels of neuropeptides observed in some brain regions in PC2 knock-out mice (33.Miller R. Toneff T. Vishnuvardhan D. Beinfeld M. Hook V.Y. Neuropeptides. 2003; 37: 140-148Crossref PubMed Scopus (41) Google Scholar).

Models of the extracellular ligand-binding domain of nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChRs), which are pentameric integral membrane proteins, are attractive for structural studies because they potentially are water-soluble and better candidates for x-ray crystallography and because their smaller size is more amenable for NMR spectroscopy. The complete N-terminal extracellular domain is a promising foundation for such models, based on previous studies of α7 and muscle-type subunits. Specific design requirements leading to high structural fidelity between extracellular domain nAChRs and full-length nAChRs, however, are not well understood. To study these requirements in heteromeric nAChRs, the extracellular domains of α4 and β2 subunits with or without the first transmembrane domain (M1) were expressed in Xenopus oocytes and compared with α4β2 nAChRs based on ligand binding and subunit assembly properties. Ligand affinities of detergent-solubilized, extracellular domain α4β2 nAChRs formed from subunits with M1 were nearly identical to affinities of α4β2 nAChRs when measured with [3H]epibatidine, cytisine, nicotine, and acetylcholine. Velocity sedimentation suggested that these extracellular domain nAChRs predominantly formed pentamers. The yield of these extracellular domain nAChRs was about half the yield of α4β2 nAChRs. In contrast, [3H]epibatidine binding was not detected from the extracellular domain α4 and β2 subunits without M1, implying no detectable expression of extracellular domain nAChRs from these subunits. These results suggest that M1 domains on both α4 and β2 play an important role for efficient expression of extracellular domain α4β2 nAChRs that are high fidelity structural models of full-length α4β2 nAChRs. To study these requirements in heteromeric nAChRs, the extracellular domains of α4 and β2 subunits with or without the first transmembrane domain (M1) were expressed in Xenopus oocytes and compared with α4β2 nAChRs based on ligand binding and subunit assembly properties. Ligand affinities of detergent-solubilized, extracellular domain α4β2 nAChRs formed from subunits with M1 were nearly identical to affinities of α4β2 nAChRs when measured with [3H]epibatidine, cytisine, nicotine, and acetylcholine. Velocity sedimentation suggested that these extracellular domain nAChRs predominantly formed pentamers. The yield of these extracellular domain nAChRs was about half the yield of α4β2 nAChRs. In contrast, [3H]epibatidine binding was not detected from the extracellular domain α4 and β2 subunits without M1, implying no detectable expression of extracellular domain nAChRs from these subunits. Ann. N. Y. Acad. Sci. 2003; 998: 41-52Crossref PubMed Scopus (151) Google Scholar, 2Gotti C. Clementi F. Prog. Neurobiol. 2004; 74: 363-396Crossref PubMed Scopus (812) Google Scholar, 3Hogg R.C. Raggenbass M. Bertrand D. Rev. Physiol. Biochem. Pharmacol. 2003; 147: 1-46Crossref PubMed Scopus (405) Google Scholar), although they also are expressed elsewhere (4Sharma G. Vijayaraghavan S. J. Neurobiol. 2002; 53: 524-534Crossref PubMed Scopus (151) Google Scholar). They are members of the superfamily of nicotinoid receptors, which includes γ-aminobutyric acid (GABA) type A and C, glycine, and serotonin 5-HT3 receptors. They contain five homologous subunits, with subunits designated α1-α10, β1-β4, δ, γ, and ϵ. Each subunit is an integral membrane protein with a large, ligand-binding N-terminal extracellular domain, four transmembrane domains (M1-M4), and a cytoplasmic loop between M3 and M4. The study of structure and dynamics of nAChRs has been motivated by their roles in normal and pathologic neurophysiology, including roles in addiction, neurodegeneration, epilepsy, myasthenia gravis, and congenital myasthenic syndromes (5Lindstrom J. Mol. Knowledge of the structure of nAChRs has come from biochemical, electrophysiological, and imaging methods (6Karlin A. Akabas M.H. Biol. 2005; 346: 967-989Crossref PubMed Scopus (1426) Google Scholar). These methods, however, do not provide comprehensive structure at atomic resolution. A significant advance toward such information has come recently from the crystallographic structure of acetylcholine-binding protein (AChBP), a water-soluble pentamer that has been the basis for homology modeling of the extracellular domain of nAChRs and other nicotinoid receptors (9Brejc K. van Dijk W.J. Continuing to move to structures of native nAChRs is needed for accurate knowledge of how these receptors function as ion channels and signal transducers, for understanding differences in pharmacological profiles and kinetics of different receptors, and for designing drugs to therapeutically target specific types of receptors for specific effects in the central and peripheral nervous systems. Structures of full-length nAChRs have been elusive because they are large, integral membrane proteins. One attractive strategy to make nAChRs more tractable for high resolution structural analysis is to produce water-soluble models from the extracellular domain without transmembrane domains. Compared with full-length nAChRs, water-soluble extracellular domain nAChRs are expected to crystallize more readily and, because of their smaller molecular mass, are expected to be better candidates for structural studies by NMR spectroscopy. This approach has shown promise for nAChRs. Models of extracellular domains of nAChRs have ranged from short amino acid sequences around the agonist-binding site (19Basus V.J. Song G. Hawrot E. These models, however, have only partially reproduced ligand binding affinities and subunit assembly properties of full-length receptors, motivating a search for models that more fully reflect the properties of full-length receptors. Extracellular domain nAChRs are defined here as comprising truncated subunits containing N-terminal extracellular domain sequences and having ligand binding affinities or subunit assembly properties similar to full-length nAChRs. They have been expressed with several subunit combinations. Dimeric extracellular domain nAChRs were produced by extracellular domains of α1 and δ subunits that also contained M1 or another membrane tether, suggesting that membrane attachment of subunits might be important for forming these extracellular domain nAChRs (31Wang Z.-Z. Hardy S.F. Hall Z.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 27575-27584Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar, 32Wang Z.-Z. Hardy S.F. Hall Z.W. J. Cell Biol. 1996; 135: 809-817Crossref PubMed Scopus (15) Google Scholar). Extracellular domains of α7 subunits linked to a glycosylphosphatidylinositol moiety were transported to the surface of Xenopus oocytes and bound α-bungarotoxin (αBgt) and d-tubocurarine (33West A.P. Bjorkman P.J. Dougherty D.A. Lester H.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 25468-25473Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (43) Google Scholar), implying the formation of multimers. Water-soluble extracellular domain α7 nAChRs without any transmembrane domains bound αBgt, nicotine, and acetylcholine with affinities similar to α7 nAChRs and likely were pentamers (34Wells G.B. Anand R. Wang F. Lindstrom J. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 964-973Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (37) Google Scholar). Their yield, however, was substantially smaller than the yield of detergent-solubilized, extracellular domain α7 nAChRs that contained M1, suggesting that M1 was important for expressing these extracellular domain nAChRs. Milligram amounts of a water-soluble, extracellular domain chimera containing α7 and AChBP sequences were produced in yeast (26Avramopoulou V. Mamalaki A. Tzartos S.J. J. Biol. Chem. 2004; 279: 38287-38293Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (34) Google Scholar). These extracellular domains formed oligomers that likely were pentamers. Water-soluble, pentameric, and extracellular domain muscle-type receptors without transmembrane domains have been demonstrated with electron microscopy (35Tierney M.L. Unwin N. J. Mol. Biol. 2000; 303: 185-196Crossref PubMed Scopus (31) Google Scholar). Different subunit combinations might more readily produce pentameric, water-soluble nAChRs than do extracellular domain α7 or muscle-type subunits. To extend the concept of extracellular domain nAChRs to other subunits and to investigate further the role of M1 in the formation of extracellular domain nAChRs, α4 and β2 subunits were studied because they produce heteromeric nAChRs and must form at least dimers to produce high affinity binding sites and because they offer potential for high level expression (36Wang D.X. Abood L.G. J. Neurosci. Res. 1996; 44: 350-354Crossref PubMed Scopus (12) Google Scholar). Extracellular domain α4 and β2 subunits with M1 produced nAChRs in Xenopus oocytes with ligand affinities nearly identical with those of α4β2 nAChRs. The subunit stoichiometry of extracellular domain α4β2 nAChRs with M1 likely was pentameric. Without M1, however, no extracellular domain nAChRs were detected, suggesting that M1 plays an important role in the efficient expression of extracellular α4β2 nAChRs. Design of Subunit DNA Plasmids—The cDNAs for human α4 subunit (37Kuryatov A. Gerzanich V. Nelson M. Olale F. Lindstrom J. J. Neurosci. 1997; 17: 9035-9047Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) and human β2 subunit (38Anand R. Lindstrom J. Nucleic Acids Res. 1990; 18: 4272Crossref PubMed Scopus (59) Google Scholar) were cloned into pSP64 poly(A) (Promega). The DNA sequences for α4M1, β2M1, α4WS, and β2WS extracellular domain constructs (Fig. 1) were derived from the α4 or β2 sequences by PCR. The N-terminal primers for PCR were GCGC AAGCTT ATG GAG CTA GGG GGC CCC GGA for both α4-derived extracellular domain constructs and GCGC CTGCAG ATG GCC CGG CGC TGC GGC CCC for both β2-derived extracellular domain constructs. The C-terminal primers for PCR were GCGC ACGCGT CTC GGA GGG CAG GTA GAA GAC for α4M1, GCGC ACGCGT GTC GGA TGG CAG GTA GAA GAC for β2M1, GCGC ACGCGT CAG CCG CCG GAT GAC GAA GGC for α4WS, and GCGC ACGCGT CTT GCG GCG AAT GAT GAA GTC for β2WS. PCR with Pfu DNA polymerase (Stratagene) was performed with 10 ng of template DNA and 50 pmol of each primer for 30 cycles in 4% Me2SO with annealing at 60 °C for 1 min and extension at 72 °C for 3 min. The α4M1 and α4WS products from PCR were cut with HindIII and MluI; the β2M1 and β2WS products were cut with PstI and MluI. These restricted PCR products were ligated into pSP64 poly(A) along with a double-stranded oligonucleotide cassette coding in-frame for two copies of the mAb 142 epitope QVTGEVIFQTPLIKNP (39Das M.K. Lindstrom J. Biochemistry. 1991; 30: 2470-2477Crossref PubMed Scopus (37) Google Scholar, 40Anand R. Bason L. Saedi M.S. Gerzanich V. Peng X. Lindstrom J. Biochemistry. 1993; 32: 9975-9984Crossref PubMed Scopus (37) Google Scholar) for α4M1, one copy of the mAb 142 epitope for α4WS, and one copy of the mAb 236 epitope VSISPESDRPDLSTF (39Das M.K. Lindstrom J. Biochemistry. 1991; 30: 2470-2477Crossref PubMed Scopus (37) Google Scholar, 40Anand R. Bason L. Saedi M.S. Gerzanich V. Peng X. Lindstrom J. Biochemistry. 1993; 32: 9975-9984Crossref PubMed Scopus (37) Google Scholar) for β2M1 and β2WS. The DNA sequences of each epitope tag contained an MluI site before and a stop codon after the sequence coding the epitope tag. To reduce the length of subunit sequence that was derived from PCR, the α4 sequence upstream from its BstYI restriction site and the β2 sequence upstream from its BsiWI were replaced by DNA sequences that were taken from the full-length subunits. The last native residues in the constructs were Glu-270 (α4 numbering from Swiss-Prot (41Bairoch A. Apweiler R. Wu C.H. Barker W.C. Boeckmann B. Ferro S. Gasteiger E. Huang H. Lopez R. Magrane M. Martin M.J. Natale D.A. O'Donovan C. Redaschi N. Yeh L.S. Nucleic Acids Res. 2005; 33: D154-D159Crossref PubMed Scopus (1416) Google Scholar) entry P43681) for α4M1, Leu-242 for α4WS, Asp-261 (β2 numbering from Swiss-Prot entry P17787) for β2M1, and Lys-233 for β2WS. The DNA sequences for α4M1NT and β2M1NT were prepared by replacing the MluI site at the 5′ end of the epitope tag coding sequence with an MluI site followed by a stop codon. The DNA sequences for α4WSNT and β2WSNT were prepared by replacing the native coding sequence distal to the BglII site near the 3′ end of α4WS and distal to the BsiWI near the 3′ end in β2WS with the identical coding sequence from synthetic oligonucleotides up to and including Leu-242 (α4WSNT) or Lys-233 (β2WSNT) followed by a stop codon. The correctness of products derived from PCR or from chemically synthesized oligonucleotides was confirmed by DNA sequencing. Protein Expression in Xenopus Oocytes—Xenopus laevis were purchased from NASCO (Fort Atkinson, WI) and maintained in 12-h light/12-h dark cycle at 18 °C. The Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee of Texas A & M University approved all animal procedures. Oocytes were prepared following standard procedures (42Matthews G.M. Higgins S.J. Protein Expression: A Practical Approach. Oxford University Press, Oxford, UK1999: 29-59Google Scholar, 43Colman A. Hames B.D. Higgins S.J. Transcription and Translation: A Practical Approach. IRL Press, Oxford, UK1984: 271-302Google Scholar), using collagenase type I (Invitrogen) for enzymatic stripping of the follicular layer. cRNA was synthesized from linearized plasmid DNA using an SP6 mMessage mMachine kit (Ambion, Austin, TX). A 40-nl aliquot containing 20 ng of cRNA for each subunit being studied was injected into the cytoplasm of each oocyte. The oocytes then were incubated at 18 °C for 3-4 days in 50% Leibovitz's L-15 medium (Invitrogen) in 10 mm HEPES, pH 7.5, containing 10 units/ml penicillin and 10 μg/ml streptomycin. The membrane-bound fraction of subunit protein was extracted from oocyte membranes by homogenizing 25-50 oocytes by hand in ice-cold buffer A (in mm: 50 sodium phosphate, 50 NaCl, 5 EDTA, 5 EGTA, 5 benzamidine, 15 iodoacetamide, pH 7.5), centrifuging this mixture for 30 min at 14,500 × g and 4 °C, solubilizing the pellet in buffer B (buffer A with 2% w/v Triton X-100) during gentle agitation for 2 h at 4 °C, and again centrifuging for 30 min at 14,500 × g and 4 °C (44Gerzanich V. Anand R. Lindstrom J. Mol. Pharm. 1994; 45: 212-220PubMed Google Scholar). The membrane fraction was defined as the detergent extract. The membrane fraction was used for immunoblotting and ligand binding assays of subunits with transmembrane domains. For α4WS, α4WSNT, β2WS, and β2WSNT, the secreted fraction from injected oocytes was defined as the L-15 medium incubating injected oocytes; the cytoplasmic fraction from injected oocytes was defined as the supernatant above the pellet after homogenizing oocytes in buffer A and centrifuging. Immunoblotting—Membrane fractions of α4M1, β2M1, α4WS, and β2WS were deglycosylated with peptide:N-glycosidase F (PNGase F, New England Biolabs), a glycosylasparaginase, according to the manufacturer's instructions. Membrane fractions were processed in parallel without PNGase F. After deglycosylation, the samples were denatured by heating at 95 °C for 90 s in 1% SDS and 15 mm dithiothreitol. The samples were run by SDS-PAGE on a 12.5% acrylamide gel and transferred to Immun-Blot™ polyvinylidene difluoride membrane (Bio-Rad) using a GENIE® electrophoretic transfer device (Idea Scientific). The membrane was blocked overnight at 4 °C with 5% powdered milk in PBS buffer and 0.05% Tween® 20. Primary antibody (mAb 142 for α4M1 and α4WS; mAb 236 for β2M1 and β2WS) at 3 nm in blocking solution was incubated with the membrane overnight at 4 °C, followed by washing for several hours with PBS and 0.05% Tween. Goat anti-rat secondary antibody conjugated with peroxidase (Pierce) was diluted 1:5000 in blocking buffer, incubated with the membrane overnight at 4 °C, and then washed several hours with PBS and 0.05% Tween. Proteins on the membrane were detected on BioMax ML film (Eastman Kodak Co.) with SuperSignal West Dura Extended Duration Substrate (Pierce) according to the manufacturer's instructions. Ligand Binding Assays—Immulon 4 HBX plastic microwells (Thermo Labsystems) for solid phase binding assays were coated with mAb 142 or mAb 236 for subunits with epitope tags (39Das M.K. Lindstrom J. Biochemistry. 1991; 30: 2470-2477Crossref PubMed Scopus (37) Google Scholar, 40Anand R. Bason L. Saedi M.S. Gerzanich V. Peng X. Lindstrom J. Biochemistry. 1993; 32: 9975-9984Crossref PubMed Scopus (37) Google Scholar); mAb 295, which binds the extracellular domain of β2 in its native conformation (45Lindstrom J. Clementi F. Fornasari D. Gotti C. Neuronal Nicotinic Receptors. Vol. 144. Springer-Verlag, Berlin2000: 101-162Google Scholar, 46Whiting P.J. Lindstrom J.M. J. Neurosci. 1988; 8: 3395-3404Crossref PubMed Google Scholar); or mAb 299 (Sigma), which binds the extracellular domain of α4 in its native or denatured conformation (45Lindstrom J. Clementi F. Fornasari D. Gotti C. Neuronal Nicotinic Receptors. Vol. 144. Springer-Verlag, Berlin2000: 101-162Google Scholar, 47Peng X. Gerzanich V. Anand R. Whiting P.J. Lindstrom J. Mol. Pharmacol. 1994; 46: 523-530PubMed Google Scholar). The wells were blocked with 3% bovine serum albumin, fraction V (EM Science), in PBS (in mm: 137 NaCl, 2.7 KCl, 1.4 KH2PO4, 10 Na2HPO4). For membrane-bound fractions, a volume of detergent extract containing the equivalent of 0.1 to 0.5 injected oocytes was added to each mAb-coated microwell. The microwells were incubated overnight at 4 °C to allow binding of epitope-tagged subunits and then washed with ice-cold buffer B. To measure [3H]epibatidine affinity, the microwells were loaded with 200 μl of (±)-[3H]epibatidine (PerkinElmer Life Sciences; specific activity ranged from 30 to 56 Ci/mmol) in ice-cold buffer B. To measure competitive inhibition by cytisine, (-)-nicotine, and acetylcholine (Sigma), the microwells were loaded with either 1 or 3 nm [3H]epibatidine and varying concentrations of inhibitor in a total volume of 200 μl of ice-cold buffer B. These two fixed concentrations of [3H]epibatidine were chosen for the competitive inhibition assays, so depletion of free [3H]epibatidine was negligible. For measuring [3H]epibatidine affinity and for measuring competitive inhibition, the microwells were incubated overnight at 4 °C to allow ligand binding. The microwells then were quickly washed with ice-cold buffer B and were stripped with a solution of 5% SDS and 25 mm dithiothreitol in buffer B. The amount of [3H]epibatidine was measured in a liquid scintillation counter. Each data point was the average of duplicate or triplicate measurements. Microwells measuring [3H]epibatidine binding from secreted fractions and cytoplasmic fractions of α4WS/β2WS or α4WSNT/β2WSNT contained 5-10 oocyte equivalents during incubation with those fractions. Processing of these microwells was similar to processing of microwells measuring membrane-bound fractions, except buffer A replaced buffer B. Nonspecific binding was measured from uninjected oocytes and was less than 5% of specific binding at 30 nm total [3H]epibatidine and was less than 1% of specific binding at concentrations below 1 nm total [3H]epibatidine. Models of [3H]Epibatidine Binding—Dissociation constants in the picomolar range have been reported for [3H]epibatidine binding to α4β2 nAChRs (48Eaton J.B. Peng J.H. Schroeder K.M. George A.A. Fryer J.D. Krishnan C. Buhlman L. Kuo Y.P. Steinlein O. Lukas R.J. Mol. Pharmacol. 2003; 64: 1283-1294Crossref PubMed Scopus (100) Google Scholar, 49Shafaee N. Houng M. Truong A. Viseshakul N. Figl A. Sandhu S. Forsayeth J.R. Dwoskin L.P. Crooks P.A. Cohen B.N. Br. J. Pharmacol. 1999; 128: 1291-1299Crossref PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar, 50Houghtling R.A. Dávila-García M.I. Kellar K.J. Mol. Pharmacol. 1995; 48: 280-287PubMed Google Scholar, 51Houghtling R.A. Dávila-García M.I. Hurt S.D. Kellar K.J. Med. Chem. Res. 1994; 4: 538-546Google Scholar). This high affinity raised the possibility of ligand depletion during binding assays. Ligand depletion means the free concentration of [3H]epibatidine differs significantly from the total concentration (52Hulme E.C. Birdsall N.J.M. Hulme E.C. Receptor-Ligand Interactions: A Practical Approach. Oxford University Press, New York1992: 63-176Google Scholar). To estimate dissociation constants for [3H]epibatidine, binding data were described with a one-site model and with cooperative and independent two-site models (Fig. 2). To allow for ligand depletion, the equations that described binding in the models were functions of the total concentration of [3H]epibatidine and did not assume free and total concentrations of [3H]epibatidine to be equal. Binding of [3H]epibatidine for the one-site model was based on the mass action Equation 1 derived from the one-site binding mechanism in Fig. 2A,Kd=R·ERE(Eq. 1) where R is the concentration of free ligand-binding sites (unbound receptor); E is the concentration of free [3H]epibatidine; RE is the concentration of bound [3H]epibatidine; and Kd is the equilibrium dissociation constant. Equation 2 describes the concentration of [3H]epibatidine-binding species RE for this model allowing for [3H]epibatidine depletion (52Hulme E.C. Birdsall N.J.M. Hulme E.C. Receptor-Ligand Interactions: A Practical Approach. Oxford University Press, New York1992: 63-176Google Scholar),RE=(Rt+Et+Kd)/2-((Rt+Et+Kd)2-4RtEt)/2(Eq. 2) where Rt and Et are the total concentrations of receptor-binding sites and of [3H]epibatidine, respectively. Equation 2 is derived from Equation 1 by substituting the conservation equations Rt = R + RE and Et = E + RE. A modified form of this equation would be needed if nonspecific binding were not negligible (53Swillens S. Mol. Pharmacol. 1995; 47: 1197-1203PubMed Google Scholar). Equations 3 and 4 describe the concentration of [3H]epibatidine-binding species for the two-cooperative site model with [3H]epibatidine depletion (Fig. 2B),RE=Kd2co(Et-Z)/(Kd2co+Z)(Eq. 3) RE2=(1/2)Z(Et-Z)/(Kd2co+Z)(Eq. 4) where RE is the total concentration of receptor with one bound [3H]epibatidine molecule; RE2 is the concentration of receptor with two bound [3H]epibatidine molecules; and Z is the concentration of free [3H]epibatidine and is the positive root of Equation 5.Z3+(2Rtco+2Kd2co-Et)Z2+(Kd1coKd2co+2RtcoKd2co-2Kd2coEt)Z-Kd1coKd2coEt=0(Eq. 5) In Equation 5, Rtco is the total concentration of receptors (each receptor with two binding sites). Equations 6 and 7 describe the concentration of [3H]epibatidine-binding species for the two-independent sites model with [3H]epibatidine depletion (Fig. 2C),R(1)E=Rt(1)Z/(Kd1in+Z)(Eq. 6) R(2)E=Rt(2)Z/(Kd2in+Z)(Eq. 7) where Z is the concentration of free [3H]epibatidine and is the positive root of Equation 8,Z3+(Rt(1)+Kd1in-Et+Kd2in+Rt(2))Z2+(Kd1inKd2in-Kd1inEt-Kd2inEt+Kd1inRt(2)+Kd2inRt(1))Z-Kd1inKd2inEt=0(Eq. 8) Inhibition of [3H]epibatidine binding by cytisine, (-)-nicotine, and acetylcholine was described with a one-site competitive inhibition model (Fig. 2D). Total concentrations of [3H]epibatidine for inhibition experiments were 1 and 3 nm. These concentrations were large enough that depletion of [3H]epibatidine and inhibitors could be neglected. Equation 9 describes the concentration of the [3H]epibatidine-binding species for the one-site competitive inhibition model,RE=KiEtRt/(KiKd+KiEt+KdIt)(Eq. 9) Based on the theory of ligand binding with ligand depletion (54Wells J.W. Hulme E.C. Receptor-Ligand Interactions: A Practical Approach. Oxford University Press, New York1992: 289-395Google Scholar, 55Wang Z.X. Jiang R.F. FEBS Lett. 1996; 392: 245-249Crossref PubMed Scopus (49) Google Scholar), Equations 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9 were derived with the program Maple (Maplesoft, Waterloo, Ontario, Canada) from the mass action equations for the two-site models and one-site competitive inhibition model, combined with the conservation equations for Rt, Rtco, Rt(1), Rt(2), Et, and It. Estimation of Dissociation Constants—Kd for the one-site binding model was estimated with two methods. First, Kd was calculated for each data set from the half-maximum concentration, K0.5, and total concentration of binding sites, Rt, as determined from least squares fitting of Equation 10 to the data set and from Equation 11,Bound[3H]epibatidine=Rt/(1+K0.5/Et)n)(Eq. 10) Kd=K0.5-(Rt/2)(Eq. 11) In Equation 10, n is the Hill coefficient.
